Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Multilevel Theory and Research: The Future of Multilevel Scholarship-May 16-17,2015; Pennsylvania State University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop builds upon the expertise and experience of a diverse set of scholars who are experts on multilevel phenomena in an effort to solve relevant problems within the organizational sciences (which naturally require a multilevel perspective, as organizationally-relevant phenomena are nested within levels across time). These scholars will present novel developments in the field, as well discuss and develop new paths for solving complex organizational problems.

The intellectual merit of the project is associated with its attention to the inherently nested nature of organizational phenomena. Scholars within the organizational sciences are increasingly aware of the complex, multilevel, and dynamic nature of applied problems within and between organizations. By including as the two keynote speakers the specific scholars whose book (Klein & Kozlowski, 2000) serves as the seminal work for modern multilevel research in the organizational sciences, the workshop will have the opportunity to look backwards and forwards in making sense of this issue. Moreover, the mixture of panel discussions, individual presentations, and group conversations will serve as a fertile context for advancing and refining new processes, models, and thoughts on multilevel theory and research.

The workshop's broader impacts are connected with its goal of developing recommendations and guidance for researchers in organizational sciences. Through the work of the experts participating in the workshop, the workshop may produce an edited volume, a special issue at a leading journal, and/or a special research forum at a top journal in an effort to disseminate cutting-edge guidance on the development and application of multilevel research in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recommendations

1. Kozlowski & Klein: Need further study to understand emergence. Need to examine integration of conputer simulation and big data to understand emergence of higher-order constructs. There is a continued need to educate scholars about multilevel theory, measurement, and analysis.

2. Aime & Argote: Field needs to theorize at multiple levels. Recommendation is to use higher-order theories to understand microdynamics (individual nested in role, nested in dyad, nested in sub-group, nested in and between teams, nested in and between departments, nested in and between organizations, nested in and between national context)

3. Corley, Gioia, & Kreiner: Leverage qualtiative data to build multilevel models. Qualitative theory is almost always inherently multilevel in nature.

4. Bliese, Knight, & Woolley: Need to develop better models for strengthening empirical reserach on emergence. Think about transference between fields.

5. Beal, Chen, Cronin, & Scott: Begin process of truly specifying dynamic models (how to effects strengthen or weaken over time?)

6. Newman & Vancouver: Simulation data can be uised to actually test many of the concerns raised today

7. Kenny: Need to make multilevel analysis even more accessible

8. Raudenbush: Need to rethink causality - multilevel approach highlights non-obvious (and counterfactual) causes

9. Aguinis, Mathieu, & Zhang: What is the intersection between approaches to multilevel research? Need to think about theory, design, sampling, measurment, and analyses simultaneously

10. Gully & Joshi: Need to consider (going forward):

a) Dynamic modeling & emergence:

b) Computational simulations

c) Qualtiative approaches

d) Multidisciplinary approaches

e) Challenging treatment of time
